description:
Mastacembelus armatus, commonly known as the spiny eel or armed spiny eel, is a species of freshwater fish that belongs to the family Mastacembelidae. It is native to parts of Asia, including India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia.

The spiny eel is an elongated, eel-like fish with a laterally compressed body and a pointed snout. It has a well-developed, cartilaginous, and spiny dorsal fin that extends along the length of its body, as well as a similar anal fin. The fish's coloration can vary, typically ranging from yellowish-brown to dark brown, with darker vertical bars or spots along its body.

Mastacembelus armatus is known to inhabit slow-moving rivers, streams, lakes, and wetlands, where it often hides among aquatic vegetation or in crevices. It is a carnivorous species that feeds on small invertebrates, crustaceans, and fish. The spiny eel is an important freshwater fish species in its native range, both for subsistence and commercial fisheries.
